title: A Pipeline For Analysing Grant Applications

sentences.text: Data mining techniques can transform massive amounts of unstructured data into quantitative data that quickly reveal insights, trends, and patterns behind the original data.

In this paper, a data mining model is applied to analyse the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency to investigate whether grant schemes successfully identifies innovative project proposals, as intended.
The grant applications are peer-reviewed research proposals that include specific 'innovation and creativity' (IC) scores assigned by reviewers.
In addition to predicting the IC score for each research proposal, we are particularly interested in understanding the vocabulary of innovative proposals.
In order to solve this problem, various data mining models and feature encoding algorithms are studied and explored.
As a result, we propose a model with the best performance, a Random Forest (RF) classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams.
In specific, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
Besides the proposed model, this paper also presents a rigorous experimental pipeline for analysing grant applications, and the experimental results prove its feasibility.
In the 21st century, the importance of developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for every country.
Therefore, each country's government research funding agencies are willing to provide much scientific research funding to support essential and cutting-edge scientific research each year.
Determining whether a scientific research project is worthy of funding is a significant and rigorous step for funding agencies.
To obtain financial support, scientists and researchers always write research proposals to present their research plans and explain the significance of the project to the funding agencies.
Usually, the government research funding agencies receive thousands of research proposals each year, which are reviewed only by expert panels.

However, with the increase in the number of research proposals and the development of data mining techniques, funding agencies are increasingly using data mining models to assist in the manual review of research proposals.
At the same time, it must be made clear that relying solely on data mining models to replace manual checks is not reliable.
Applying data mining models to a research proposal has several benefits.

First, data mining models can briefly introduce the essential features of the research proposals to help human evaluators better screen the excellent research proposals, such as the influential features of the data mining models across all the research proposals.
Second, an effective data mining model can help human evaluators understand the research proposals’ strengths and weaknesses during the manual review process.
Next, a high-quality data mining model can be applied to develop procedures and guidelines for human assessors to evaluate future research proposals to improve the quality of assessments.
Fourth, for government or funding agencies, different funding projects should be established to improve the quality of various types of research.
Data mining models can better understand how to ensure that human evaluators respond to these necessary qualities.

Based on the benefits and motivations mentioned above, we hope to apply a data mining model with an appropriate feature extraction technique to predict high IC-score research proposals based on the IC scores assigned by the expert reviewers.

Meanwhile, the other primary goal of the project is to develop a predictive vocabulary for contemporaneous proposals and to understand how the model inferred research proposals with high IC scores from the data features.

In addition, we focus on proposing an efficient feature extraction technique rather than the choice of classifiers, so we choose the very common Decision Tree (DT) and RF classifiers for experimental comparison.
The contributions of this paper are listed as follows:
A strict experimental pipeline for analysing grant applications is given, and the experimental results prove its feasibility.
A model is proposed with a Random Forest classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigram terms.
The unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
The proposed model for predicting high IC-score research proposals can achieve an accuracy of 84.17% across all types of grant applications.
This paper is divided into six sections.
In the first section, the project's motivation and problem statement are briefly introduced.
In section 2, the background and related work of this project are introduced.
The methodology section mainly describes the pipeline we apply for this research project.
Section 4 brings the overall design of the project.
Then, the experimental settings and implementations with the hardware platforms are introduced in this section.
The fifth section gives the experimental results of this project and carries on the further analysis.
Conclusions and future work are described in section 6.
2.1 Computer science in evaluating grant applications.
Oztaysi et al. [2] proposed a multi-criteria approach to evaluate research proposals based on interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets.
In this method, a fuzzy preference relation matrix was used to determine the relative importance of criteria.
The Preference Selection Index (PSI) was another interesting method to evaluate research grant applications [3].
One advantage of applying the PSI method was that the researcher did not need to determine the weight criteria.
Another similar and recently related work was the research paper classification system built based on the TF-IDF and LDA schemes [4].
This system used a Latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) scheme to extract representative keywords from the abstract of each paper [5].
The K-means clustering algorithm [6] was applied to group papers with similar topics based on the TF-IDF vector encoding of each paper.
The results showed that the LDA with 30 keywords using TF-IDF obtained the best F-score compared with the LDA with fewer keywords.
2.2 Term vectors and statistical measures in text representation.
TF-IDF is commonly used in data mining and information retrieval.
TF indicates the frequency of a word in a document or a collection of documents.
When calculating TF, all the words from documents are treated as equally important.
However, in practice, people only pay attention to a certain of words.
For example, “this", “are", and “it" usually do not represent important in most cases.
Then, the IDF is implemented to adjust the term weights in documents which can increase the weights of those rare but important words and weigh down those frequent words but less important.
In 2016, Guo and Yang [7] analysed the shortcomings of the TF-IDF algorithm.
Then, an intra-class dispersion algorithm based on TF-IDF was proposed.
Chen et al. [8] proposed a new term weighting technique called Term Frequency & Inverse Gravity Moment (TF-IGM), which was mainly used to measure the class discrimination of a term.
The experimental results showed that the TF-IGM performed better than the traditional TF-IDF in three standard corpora.
Das and Chakraborty [9] proposed a text sentiment classification technique based on the TF-IDF algorithm and Next Word Negation (NWN).
In addition, this study also compared the binary bag of words, TF-IDF, and TF-IDF with NWN algorithms.
Fan and Qin [10] proposed another improved TF-IDF algorithm, TF-IDCRF, which focused on the relationship between classes in the classification model.
In 2019, an improved TF-IDF algorithm based on classification discrimination strength was proposed for text classification [11].
2.3 Data mining models in text classification.
In the field of data mining, the DT classifier is widely welcome for its advantage of showing how models make decisions according to the data features [12].
RF classifier is another popular data mining model.
The term forest can be interpreted to mean that each classifier in the ensemble is a DT classifier, while all combinations of classifiers are a forest [13].
In the RF classifier, each decision tree also selects the optimal attribute based on the Attribute Selection Measures (ASM).
At the same time, each decision tree depends independently on a random sample.
The RF classifier votes on each tree in specific classification problems and selects the most popular category as the final result.
In 2016, a news classification method was proposed based on the TF-IDF algorithm and Support Vector Machine (SVM) [14].
Based on a different number of n-grams and various data sets, five data mining classifiers were built and compared [15].
The results can guide researchers to select an appropriate data mining model according to the size of the data set.

Four different data mining models were implemented with five different ensemble methods, and the experimental results showed that the RF classifier with the Bagging ensemble method achieved the best performance [16].
Wongso et al. [17] applied TF-IDF and SVD algorithms [18] to the feature selection step and compare the two algorithms.
At the same time, the Multivariate Bernoulli Naive Bayes [19], and SVM were compared in this study.
Finally, with the combination of TF-IDF and Multivariate Bernoulli Naive Bayes, news articles in the Indonesian Language corpus were classified, and the best result was obtained [17].
This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model.
Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications.
3.1 Data set.
The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency.
3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7).
In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants.
Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.”
Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary.
A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content.
By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index.
Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals.
At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score.
Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores.
In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project.
Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.
3.2 Text pre-processing for grant applications.
HaCohen-Kerner et al. [22] proved that text pre-processing techniques could make the model achieve better performance than without the text pre-processing step.
After all the text is extracted, all characters, whether uppercase or lowercase, are converted to lowercase.
Then, the numbers are also removed because the numbers in the research proposals are not relevant for future analysis.
Thirdly, removing punctuations and tokenizing by whitespace are also adopted, which make the text into small pieces called tokens.
In addition, the deletion of stop words is one of the most crucial text pre-processing techniques.
Fani et al. [23] have shown that deleting stop words can improve the performance of data mining tasks.
Therefore, we create a list of custom stop words according to the IDF formula and delete the IDF value of the term from the text lower than 1.0.
The reason for choosing 1.0 is that after implementation some preliminary experiments, we confirm that the feature words considered as important by DT and RF classifiers will less than 1000 words.
Meanwhile, the words whose IDF value are less than 1.0 only account for 0.2% of the total words, and they are all common words such as “next”, “shift” and “other”.
We believe that these words appear too frequently and have no influence on the experimental results.
Finally, text stemming is the last technique we apply in the text pre-processing step.
Text stemming is a technique for reducing each word to its root format [24].
It helps to reduce the vocabulary and surface syntax to get closer to the meaning of each term, and the Porter Stemming algorithm [25] is implemented in this step.
This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model.
Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications.
3.1 Data set.
The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency.
3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7).
In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants.
Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.”
Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary.
A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content.
By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index.
Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals.
At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score.
Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores.
In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project.
Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.
3.4 Design and apply the feature extraction technique.
We propose a modified TF-IDF algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF as the feature extraction technique.
In specific, if the term exists at least once in the documents, specify the IDF value for this term directly.
In addition, if a term does not exist in the documents, then the term is assigned a value of 0.
The design of this modified feature extraction algorithm follows the idea that rare terms can define innovativeness.
The experiment also considers the n-grams [26].

Unigram is the most common choice for text classification tasks, but bigram and trigram may better represent scientific terms, where bigram is two consecutive words in a sentence, and trigram is three consecutive words in a sentence.
At the same time, when collecting proposals, we also consider deleting the words that only exist once or twice, because very rare terms tend not to be predictive.
In addition, the bigram mentioned in this paper denotes a combination of the unigrams and bigrams.
The trigram denotes a combination of the unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams.
3.5 Apply data mining models with grant applications.

This paper uses DT and RF classifiers for text classification because we would like to find out the most influential terms and understood how the data mining model predicts high and low IC-score research proposals.
The DT and RF classifiers are convenient to present this valuable information.

Based on the experimental result of the high and low IC-score research proposals selection, all experiments are conducted with the low IC-score research proposals (IC score 0~15%) and the high IC-score research proposals (IC score 85%~100%).

In the comparison study of feature extraction techniques, 400 research proposals for each low and high IC score are randomly selected for model training, and the training data is 85%, and the test data is 15%.

In order to analyse the proposed model in the end, the 100 most influential terms from the collections of research proposals are extracted by the function from scikit-learn library [27], which bring us an intuitive understanding of how much each term contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.
3.6 Analyse moderate IC-score grant applications.
We also conduct several experiments to analyse moderate IC-score research proposals based on the proposed model.
The purpose of this series of experiments is to determine whether there is a relation between proposals with moderate IC scores and that of high and low IC scores.
Since the proposed model is trained based on the low IC-score proposals of 0~15% and high IC-score proposals of 85~100%, the range of research proposals with moderate IC score is 15%~85%.
Based on the median IC score, the selection range of testing moderate IC score by testing several cut-off options, such as 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50.
Table 4 shows a list of experiments used to analyse the research proposals of moderate IC score.

Considering the symmetric distribution of the IC scores, new research proposals with low and high IC scores are selected in each experiment, and performance analysis is conducted based on the proposed training model.

In addition to the experiments in Table 4, another experiment is designed to check the median IC-score research proposals (IC score = 5.0) to predict the proportion of high or low IC-score research proposals rather than calculate the test accuracy.
This section describes all experimental settings for this paper.
Initially, MEL [20] is implemented through a set of Python-based methods to extract metadata for all supported file types.
To extract metadata from the PDF version of a file, the Tesseract-OCR method [28] and pdftotext tool [29] are applied.
In the statistical analysis of grant applications, the Python language and Numpy library [30] are used to calculate the median, mode, and other statistical measurements of IC score.

In the experiments of selecting high, low, and moderate IC-score research proposals and implementing the data mining models, the scikit-learn library [27] is applied to implement the DT and RF classifiers.
The python library gensim [31] is used to implement the TF-IDF algorithm and the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm.
Hyper-parameter tuning is a significant step in applying data mining models, and the Bayesian Optimization tool [32] is applied.
The first step to implement Bayesian Optimization is to define the data mining model, such as the RF classifier and its parameters and corresponding bounds.
In addition, we also need to implement the scoring method and the cross-validation setup.
Secondly, the maximize method is used to run the technique with n_iter and init_points parameters.
The n_iter is defined for the number of steps to run the optimization function.
The more steps, the easier it is to find the best accuracy value.
The init_points is defined for random exploration on the parameter space, which helps to explore the diversity of the space.
Finally, the parameter values for each accuracy are listed, highlighting the best combination of the parameter and the target value.

To find the hyper-parameters of the RF classifier, the range of each parameter is set as follows: max_depth = (5, 60), min_samples_split = (10, 100), max_features = (0.1, 0.999), max_samples_leaf = (10, 50) and n_estimation = (100, 400).
For the DT classifier, the range settings for finding hyper-parameters are as follows: max_depth = (3, 10), min_samples_split = (3, 10), max_features = (0.1, 0.999),and max_samples_leaf = (3, 10).
The max_depth parameter indicates the maximum depth of the tree, and the max_features denotes the number of features to consider when finding the best split [27].

The parameters min_samples_leaf, min_samples_split, and n_estimators are defined as the minimum number of samples needed on a leaf node, the minimum number of samples needed to split an internal node, and the number of trees in the forest, respectively.
All experiments related to RF classifier and DT classifier adopt the same setting of the hyper-parameter range.
Meanwhile, the 10-fold cross-validation method is also applied in finding the hyper-parameters.

To evaluate the performance of the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm and the TF-IDF algorithm with different data mining classifiers, the classification accuracy (Acc), F1 score are selected as the evaluation metrics.
The hardware platform is MacBook Pro with Intel Core i7 2.9 GHz Quard-Core processor.
The memory configuration is 16GB 2133 MHz LPDDR3.
Table 5 shows the performance of the TF-IDF algorithm with DT and RF classifiers.
It can be found that the RF classifier can consistently achieve better performance than the DT classifier under the different settings of the n-grams and deletion of rare terms.
Table 6 shows the performance of the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm with DT and RF classifiers.

Based on the comparison of Table 5 and Table 6, the best performance is achieved with 84.17% accuracy by the RF classifier with the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm except the No.14 model combination in Table 6.
The hyper-parameters are max_depth = 22, max_features = 0.9931, min_samples_leaf = 11, min_samples_split = 67 and n_estimation = 102.
To include all the terms from the corpus, we choose the RF classifier based on unigram and the modified TF-IDF algorithm as the final proposed model.
Another reason why we do not choose the bigram and trigram combinations as the proposed model is the bigram and trigram terms are in fact not regarded as essential features by DT and RF classifiers.
Features extracted from the proposed model shows that only 618 features are considered significant, based on tens of thousands of features in the research proposals.
Based on the comparison of the two tables, it can be found that the proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm is practical and effective despite two or three exceptions exist.
At the same time, the experimental results prove that the core idea of defining the modified TF-IDF algorithm is meaningful and show the rare terms associated with innovativeness.

It should also be noted that the newly proposed modified TF-IDF algorithm can be understood as a simple encoding technique, such as taking the value 0 or the IDF value of the term depending on whether the term exists in the research proposals.

Based on the decision tree plots generated by the best performance model, it can be found that the modified TF-IDF algorithm does not affect the shape of the tree as seen in the tree graph, helping to understand whether the chosen split term is rare or common.

From the result of finding hyper-parameters, it can be found that the best performing model does not use all the features to apply with the data mining algorithms, such as the RF classifier only uses 99.31% features.
In addition, although we consider different n-grams, especially bigram and trigram, with removing scarce words, Table 5 and Table 6 could prove that it might help but not always.
Moreover, based on the same feature extraction algorithm, the classification accuracy of the RF classifier is always better than that of the DT classifier.
Nevertheless, the results of the DT classifier are still crucial because the plot of DT classifier contains all the decisions.
Fig. 2 shows the confusion matrix of the proposed model for the “unseen” test data.
It shows 13 high IC-score research proposals are incorrectly predicted as low IC-score proposals.
In addition, 6 research proposals with low IC scores are guessed wrongly which they are predicted as high IC-score proposals.
The number 59 denotes that the proposed model correctly predicts 59 research proposals with low IC scores and 42 with high IC scores.

In addition to analysing the confusion matrix, we also extract the 100 most influential features from the proposed model, which gives an intuitive understanding of how much each feature contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.
The top 100 features give us a better understanding of what is going on inside the black box.
A measure of the feature importance is valuable for internal model development purposes by showing to what extent features contribute to test data.

Although the classifier is only established for the 2019 grant applications and may not predict the high research proposals for future applications, these unique terms are still valuable and meaningful as a reference for evaluators.
Table 7 brings the performance of checking research proposals of moderate IC scores based on the proposed model.
Based on the test accuracy, it can be concluded that there is a correlation between the moderate IC-score research proposals and high/low IC-score research proposals.
Moreover, it is easy to find that the proposed model can better predict the research proposals close to the original training set settings (0~15% for low IC score and 85%~100% for high IC score).

Based on the confusion matrix above and the experimental results of checking moderate IC-score research proposals, it can be found that the model is always more accurate in predicting research proposals with low IC scores than with high IC scores.
Meanwhile, the research proposals with the median IC score of 5.0 are predicted to be about 37.2% with high-IC score research proposals and about 62.8% with low-IC score research proposals.
Therefore, it can be concluded that research proposals with high IC scores use more diverse language than those with low IC-score.
In addition to the experiments analysing all grant applications, we follow the same pipeline and establish a new model to evaluate Ideas Grant applications only, the one with innovation criteria.
Applying the same method but with different hyper-parameters, the best performing model for analysing the Ideas Grants can reach an accuracy of 82.5%.
In every Ideas Grant application, there is a section called “Innovation and Creativity statement.”
We also extract this part from each Ideas grant and analyse using the proposed pipeline.
The experimental result shows that the proposed method can achieve 68.33% accuracy on analysing “Innovation and Creativity statement” sections only from Ideas Grants.

Although we guess the IC score is more relevant to the “Innovation and Creativity statement” compared with other sections, as evaluators may describe their innovation in this section, the experimental result does not support our guess.
In summary, a pipeline for analysing grant applications has been proposed with several crucial steps.
The proposed data mining model is an RF classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams.
Specifically, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency(TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF.
As a result, the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 84.17% based on all types of grant applications.
In addition, we also build experiments for Ideas Grants only and “Innovation and Creativity statement” single section.
The future work can be carried out from different perspectives.
Firstly, innovation should not be the only evaluation criterion.

In order to better evaluate the entire grant application, we should consider other evaluation scores and establish a more comprehensive system that can predict a grant application based on multiple criteria.
Secondly, in the future, this project can also apply some other effective data mining models, such as SVM, AdaBoost, and Xgboost.
In addition, the pre-trained language models in the Natural Language Processing (NLP) field perform well in understanding text semantics, which can also be our next research focus.
Thirdly, our proposed method cannot predict future grant applications because the current data set contains only key terms for 2019 and does not represent future grant applications.
Therefore, it is an important research topic to consider building a long-term data mining model to predict future grant applications.

summary:
A data mining model was applied to analyze Australian Government research grant applications from 2019, aiming to identify innovative project proposals using a Random Forest classifier and unigram features.

Governments use data mining models with feature extraction techniques like Decision Tree or Random Forest classifiers to review research proposals, improving evaluation quality and achieving an accuracy of 84.17%.

Computer science methods for evaluating grant applications include multi-criteria approaches using interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets and Preference Selection Index (PSI), as well as text representation techniques like TF-IDF to adjust term weights.

This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model. Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications. 3.1 Data set. The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency. 3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7). In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants. Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.” Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary. A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content. By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index. Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals. At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score. Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores. In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project. Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.

3.2 Text pre-processing for grant applications. HaCohen-Kerner et al. [22] proved that text pre-processing techniques could make the model achieve better performance than without the text pre-processing step. After all the text is extracted, all characters, whether uppercase or lowercase, are converted to lowercase. Then, the numbers are also removed because the numbers in the research proposals are not relevant for future analysis. Thirdly, removing punctuations and tokenizing by whitespace are also adopted, which make the text into small pieces called tokens. In addition, the deletion of stop words is one of the most crucial text pre-processing techniques. Fani et al. [23] have shown that deleting stop words can improve the performance of data mining tasks. Therefore, we create a list of custom stop words according to the IDF formula and delete the IDF value of the term from the text lower than 1.0. The reason for choosing 1.0 is that after implementation some preliminary experiments, we confirm that the feature words considered as important by DT and RF classifiers will less than 1000 words. Meanwhile, the words whose IDF value are less than 1.0 only account for 0.2% of the total words, and they are all common words such as “next”, “shift” and “other”. We believe that these words appear too frequently and have no influence on the experimental results. Finally, text stemming is the last technique we apply in the text pre-processing step. Text stemming is a technique for reducing each word to its root format [24]. It helps to reduce the vocabulary and surface syntax to get closer to the meaning of each term, and the Porter Stemming algorithm [25] is implemented in this step.

This section details the workflow of our proposed pipeline and the data mining model. Fig. 1 shows the pipeline of analysing grant applications. 3.1 Data set. The data set used to analyse the grant applications is the 2019 grant applications submitted to an Australian Government research funding agency. 3,805 research proposals are given in this data set with peer-reviewed IC scores (1 - 7). In addition, the entire data set contains different types of grant applications, such as Synergy Grants, Standard Project Grants, and Ideas Grants. Besides the IC score, reviewers also score several other assessment scores, such as “Feasibility Score” or “Significance Score.” Since all research proposals are saved in PDF format, extracting the text from PDF files is necessary. A Metadata Extractor & Loader (MEL) [20] tool is applied to extract text from PDF research proposals and save it in a JSON file with metadata sets and content. By default, all JSON files are stored in CouchDB database [21] based on the proposal index. Before designing the whole pipeline, a statistical analysis is required based on the IC scores of research proposals. At the same time, some fundamental values are also the basis of designing the entire pipeline, such as the median IC score and mode IC score. Table 1 shows a statistic of IC scores, showing that 3,693 research proposals have valid IC scores. In addition, 99 research proposals do not contain an IC score, 13 of which have an IC score below 1.0, and these research proposals therefore not be used in this project. Table 1 also shows the median IC score, 5.0, the most frequent IC score.

3.4 Design and apply the feature extraction technique. We propose a modified TF-IDF algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF as the feature extraction technique. In specific, if the term exists at least once in the documents, specify the IDF value for this term directly. In addition, if a term does not exist in the documents, then the term is assigned a value of 0. The design of this modified feature extraction algorithm follows the idea that rare terms can define innovativeness. The experiment also considers the n-grams [26]. Unigram is the most common choice for text classification tasks, but bigram and trigram may better represent scientific terms, where bigram is two consecutive words in a sentence, and trigram is three consecutive words in a sentence. At the same time, when collecting proposals, we also consider deleting the words that only exist once or twice, because very rare terms tend not to be predictive. In addition, the bigram mentioned in this paper denotes a combination of the unigrams and bigrams. The trigram denotes a combination of the unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams.

3.5 Apply data mining models with grant applications. This paper uses DT and RF classifiers for text classification because we would like to find out the most influential terms and understood how the data mining model predicts high and low IC-score research proposals. The DT and RF classifiers are convenient to present this valuable information. Based on the experimental result of the high and low IC-score research proposals selection, all experiments are conducted with the low IC-score research proposals (IC score 0~15%) and the high IC-score research proposals (IC score 85%~100%). In the comparison study of feature extraction techniques, 400 research proposals for each low and high IC score are randomly selected for model training, and the training data is 85%, and the test data is 15%. In order to analyse the proposed model in the end, the 100 most influential terms from the collections of research proposals are extracted by the function from scikit-learn library [27], which bring us an intuitive understanding of how much each term contributes to reducing the weighted impurities.

3.6 Analyse moderate IC-score grant applications. We also conduct several experiments to analyse moderate IC-score research proposals based on the proposed model. The purpose of this series of experiments is to determine whether there is a relation between proposals with moderate IC scores and that of high and low IC scores. Since the proposed model is trained based on the low IC-score proposals of 0~15% and high IC-score proposals of 85~100%, the range of research proposals with moderate IC score is 15%~85%. Based on the median IC score, the selection range of testing moderate IC score by testing several cut-off options, such as 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50. Table 4 shows a list of experiments used to analyse the research proposals of moderate IC score. Considering the symmetric distribution of the IC scores, new research proposals with low and high IC scores are selected in each experiment, and performance analysis is conducted based on the proposed training model. In addition to the experiments in Table 4, another experiment is designed to check the median IC-score research proposals (IC score = 5.0) to predict the proportion of high or low IC-score research proposals rather than calculate the test accuracy.

This paper uses Python-based methods to extract metadata from various file types, with statistical analysis performed using Numpy, scikit-learn, and gensim. Hyper-parameter tuning was done for RF and DT classifiers.

The TF-IDF algorithm with RF classifier outperforms DT classifier under different settings, achieving practical and effective results despite some exceptions. The best-performing model uses only 99.31% features.

In summary, a pipeline for analysing grant applications has been proposed with several crucial steps. The proposed data mining model is an RF classifier over documents encoded with features denoting the presence or absence of unigrams. Specifically, the unigram terms are encoded by a modified Term Frequency - Inverse Document Frequency(TF-IDF) algorithm, which only implements the IDF part of TF-IDF. As a result, the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 84.17% based on all types of grant applications. In addition, we also build experiments for Ideas Grants only and “Innovation and Creativity statement” single section.

The future work can be carried out from different perspectives. Firstly, innovation should not be the only evaluation criterion. In order to better evaluate the entire grant application, we should consider other evaluation scores and establish a more comprehensive system that can predict a grant application based on multiple criteria. Secondly, in the future, this project can also apply some other effective data mining models, such as SVM, AdaBoost, and Xgboost. In addition, the pre-trained language models in the Natural Language Processing (NLP) field perform well in understanding text semantics, which can also be our next research focus. Thirdly, our proposed method cannot predict future grant applications because the current data set contains only key terms for 2019 and does not represent future grant applications. Therefore, it is an important research topic to consider building a long-term data mining model to predict future grant applications.

Predicate-transform.label: transform
Predicate-transform.description: To convert or change something from one form to another, often involving a significant alteration or reorganization. This predicate indicates that the subject has taken an object and changed its nature, structure, or representation.

Predicate-reveal.label: reveal
Predicate-reveal.description: To reveal means to uncover or disclose previously unknown or hidden information about a subject, making it accessible and understandable. The predicate 'reveal' connects the subject (the source of the information) with the object (the insights, trends, and patterns that are discovered), indicating that the process of analysis or examination has led to new understanding.

Predicate-successfully_identifies.label: successfully identifies
Predicate-successfully_identifies.description: The predicate 'successfully identifies' indicates that the subject (in this case, grant schemes) has recognized or pinpointed a specific characteristic, attribute, or quality about the object (innovative project proposals), suggesting accuracy and effectiveness in its identification process.

Predicate-applied_to.label: applied to
Predicate-applied_to.description: The predicate 'applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or method) is used, implemented, or put into practice for the purpose of analyzing, processing, or manipulating the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject's capabilities are being leveraged to achieve some specific goal or outcome related to the object.

Predicate-are_studied.label: are studied
Predicate-are_studied.description: The predicate 'are studied' indicates a relationship of academic inquiry or investigation between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (Data mining models, in this case) are being examined, analyzed, or explored with respect to the object (feature encoding algorithms), which may involve theoretical frameworks, methodologies, or practical applications.

Predicate-classifier.label: classifier
Predicate-classifier.description: A predicate that indicates a subject's role in categorizing or classifying an object based on its characteristics. The classifier connects the subject (a machine learning algorithm, model, or system) to the object (data, instances, or items), highlighting how the subject processes and organizes the object into distinct categories.

Predicate-are_encoded_by.label: are encoded by
Predicate-are_encoded_by.description: The predicate 'are encoded by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a set of entities or concepts) has its characteristics, features, or properties represented or translated into a specific form or structure defined by the object. The object typically represents an encoding scheme, algorithm, or method that transforms or maps the subject's inherent qualities onto a particular representation.

Predicate-proves.label: proves
Predicate-proves.description: To prove something means to demonstrate or show that it is true, valid, or effective through evidence, argumentation, or experimentation. The predicate 'proves' connects the subject (the entity providing proof) with the object (what is being proven), indicating a causal relationship where the subject's existence or demonstration leads to the conclusion that the object is indeed the case.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or essential element that must be present in order for something to exist, happen, or be achieved. It implies a sense of necessity, obligation, or expectation between the subject and object.

Predicate-is_self-evident_for_every_coun.label: is self-evident for every country
Predicate-is_self-evident_for_every_coun.description: The predicate 'is self-evident for every country' indicates a universal truth or obvious fact that applies to all countries. It suggests that the subject (developing cutting-edge scientific research, etc.) is inherently true and widely accepted by everyone across different nations.

Predicate-developing_cutting-edge_scient.label: developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for
Predicate-developing_cutting-edge_scient.description: The predicate 'developing cutting-edge scientific research is self-evident for' indicates a connection between the subject and object such that the development of advanced scientific inquiry is inherently justified or obvious, given the context provided by the object. The object serves as a backdrop against which the significance or necessity of developing cutting-edge scientific research becomes apparent.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or organization) offers, supplies, or makes available something to support or facilitate the object. In general, it implies a sense of giving or offering resources, services, or information that can be used by others.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: The predicate 'is' connects the subject to an attribute or characteristic that defines its nature, essence, or identity. It establishes a state of being between the subject and object, indicating that they share a common property or quality.

Predicate-write.label: write
Predicate-write.description: To write means to create written content that represents or conveys information, ideas, or concepts. The subject of this predicate typically possesses the ability and intention to produce written material, which can take various forms such as texts, reports, proposals, articles, etc. In general, writing involves transforming thoughts, experiences, or knowledge into a tangible form using language.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject (e.g. scientists and researchers) are currently engaged with or showcasing something about themselves, such as their thoughts, ideas, findings, plans, etc., which is represented by the object (their research plans). In a general sense, this predicate connects the subject to their current state of being or activity.

Predicate-explain.label: explain
Predicate-explain.description: To explain means to clarify or interpret the meaning of something (the object), typically by providing a logical justification, analysis, or demonstration that connects it to relevant concepts, principles, or experiences. The subject, in this case scientists and researchers, are responsible for rendering the object comprehensible, often through a process of reasoning, illustration, or example.

Predicate-are_increasingly_using_data_mi.label: are increasingly using data mining models to assist in the manual review of
Predicate-are_increasingly_using_data_mi.description: This predicate indicates that an entity (the subject) employs a specific technique or method (data mining models) to facilitate and improve their process of reviewing or evaluating another entity's work, information, or application (the object).

Predicate-receive.label: receive
Predicate-receive.description: To receive indicates a subject's acquisition or acceptance of something from an external source. The predicate establishes a relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has obtained or taken possession of the object.

Predicate-review.label: review
Predicate-review.description: To review means to examine and evaluate the quality or value of something (the object), typically with a critical eye, in order to form an opinion or make a judgment about it. The subject, often an entity with expertise or authority, engages in this process to gain insight, identify strengths and weaknesses, or provide feedback on the object.

Predicate-receive_thousands_of_research_.label: receive thousands of research proposals each year, which are reviewed only by
Predicate-receive_thousands_of_research_.description: This predicate indicates that a subject entity receives a large quantity (thousands) of research proposal submissions annually. The proposals received are then evaluated or reviewed by an object entity, which provides expertise and oversight to ensure the quality and suitability of the proposed research.

Predicate-are_using.label: are using
Predicate-are_using.description: The predicate 'are using' indicates a relationship of utilization or application between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject entity (research funding agencies, for example) employs, exploits, or makes use of the object entity (Data mining models, in this case), possibly to achieve some goal or accomplish a specific task.

Predicate-has_several_benefits_when_appl.label: has several benefits when applied to
Predicate-has_several_benefits_when_appl.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (e.g., a concept, method, or technique) yields multiple advantages or positive outcomes when used or applied to the object (e.g., a specific domain, context, or application). The connection between the subject and object is one of potential utility or effectiveness.

Predicate-can_briefly_introduce.label: can briefly introduce
Predicate-can_briefly_introduce.description: The predicate 'can briefly introduce' indicates that the subject has the ability to concisely present or summarize the key aspects of the object. This implies a relationship where the subject possesses knowledge, understanding, or expertise about the object and can effectively convey its essential characteristics in a concise manner.

Predicate-are_screened_by.label: are screened by
Predicate-are_screened_by.description: The predicate 'are screened by' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, excellent research proposals) undergoes evaluation or assessment by another entity (the object), typically with the goal of identifying relevant characteristics, qualities, or features. This connection implies that the subject is being examined and filtered through some process or mechanism to determine its suitability for further consideration.

Predicate-can_help.label: can help
Predicate-can_help.description: The predicate 'can help' indicates a potential or possible assistance relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has the capability to render aid, support, or guidance to the object, which may be an individual, group, organization, or even another entity.

Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.label: can be applied to develop
Predicate-can_be_applied_to_develop.description: The predicate 'can be applied to develop' indicates that the subject has a potential or capacity to contribute to the creation of something new (the object), often by providing insights, guidance, or expertise. In general, this predicate suggests a relationship where the subject serves as a foundation or starting point for developing the object.

Predicate-evaluate.label: evaluate
Predicate-evaluate.description: To evaluate means to assess or judge the quality, value, or significance of something based on certain criteria or standards. The subject (human evaluators) applies their expertise and judgment to determine the worthiness or effectiveness of the object (future research proposals), making a critical assessment that can influence decisions or outcomes.

Predicate-establish.label: establish
Predicate-establish.description: To establish means to create and set up a new entity, process, or system that did not previously exist. This predicate indicates the subject's intentional action of bringing something into being, often with a sense of permanence or stability.

Predicate-can_better_understand_how_to_e.label: can better understand how to ensure that
Predicate-can_better_understand_how_to_e.description: This predicate indicates a relationship where the subject has the capacity or ability to comprehend and grasp the object's requirements for ensuring something. The subject can develop an understanding of how to guarantee that the object achieves its goals, objectives, or standards.

Predicate-respond_to.label: respond to
Predicate-respond_to.description: The predicate 'respond to' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. human evaluators) exhibit or demonstrate a reaction, behavior, or characteristic that corresponds to or matches the object (e.g. these necessary qualities). This connection implies an evaluation, assessment, or judgment made by the subject based on their understanding of the object.

Predicate-apply.label: apply
Predicate-apply.description: To utilize or put into practice a specific method, approach, or strategy to achieve a particular outcome. The predicate 'apply' indicates that the subject (Data mining models) uses or employs the object (feature extraction technique) for a certain purpose.

Predicate-predict.label: predict
Predicate-predict.description: To predict means to form an expectation or estimation about a future event or outcome based on available information and analysis. The predicate 'predict' connects the subject (the entity making the prediction) with the object (the expected outcome), indicating that the subject has formed a forecast or anticipation of what will happen.

Predicate-assign.label: assign
Predicate-assign.description: To assign means to allocate or designate something (in this case, the object) as a specific value, role, or responsibility for someone or something else. The subject of the predicate 'assign' takes on the task of determining what the object should be, and in doing so, defines its purpose or function.

Predicate-to_predict_high_IC-score_resea.label: to predict high IC-score research proposals based on the IC scores assigned by the expert reviewers
Predicate-to_predict_high_IC-score_resea.description: This predicate describes a process of identifying and selecting research proposals that are likely to have high IC-scores based on the scores assigned by expert reviewers. The subject, which can be an entity or system capable of processing data (e.g., a model), uses the IC scores as input to predict which research proposals meet certain criteria for quality or relevance.

Predicate-is_to_develop_and_understand_h.label: is to develop and understand how the model inferred research proposals with high IC scores from the data features.
Predicate-is_to_develop_and_understand_h.description: This predicate describes the process of analyzing and interpreting the results obtained by applying machine learning models to identify research proposal topics with high IC scores, based on specific data features. It highlights the subject's (project) role in developing an understanding of how these models work and what insights they provide.

Predicate-develops.label: develops
Predicate-develops.description: The predicate 'develops' indicates that the subject has created or brought into being something new or improved from what was previously available, often through a process of growth, refinement, or innovation. The object represents the outcome or result of this development.

Predicate-choose.label: choose
Predicate-choose.description: The predicate 'choose' represents a selection or decision-making process that connects the subject to one or more options. It indicates that the subject has selected or opted for one of the possible alternatives, which are represented by the object.

Predicate-are_listed_as_follows.label: are listed as follows
Predicate-are_listed_as_follows.description: The predicate 'are listed as follows' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g. contributions) provides an exhaustive or representative enumeration of items that are subsequently specified by the object (e.g. this paper). The phrase suggests a structured presentation, often with a focus on clarity and organization.

Predicate-has_a.label: has a
Predicate-has_a.description: The predicate 'has a' indicates possession or association between two entities. It suggests that the subject entity possesses, contains, or is related to the object entity in some way.

Predicate-proposed_with.label: proposed with
Predicate-proposed_with.description: The predicate 'proposed with' indicates that the subject and object are related in a way where the subject has been paired, associated, or linked to the object for some purpose. This connection implies a sense of compatibility, suitability, or feasibility between the two entities.

Predicate-over.label: over
Predicate-over.description: The predicate 'over' indicates a relationship where the subject has control or influence over the object. It suggests that the subject operates on, governs, or dominates the object in some way.

Predicate-implements_the_IDF_part_of.label: implements the IDF part of
Predicate-implements_the_IDF_part_of.description: This predicate indicates that the subject is responsible for extracting or utilizing a specific component (the 'IDF part') from an overall concept or framework (the object), which in this case happens to be TF-IDF. The connection between the subject and object suggests a relationship of decomposition, where the subject breaks down the object into its constituent parts.

Predicate-predicts.label: predicts
Predicate-predicts.description: The predicate 'predicts' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject has the ability to foresee or anticipate the outcome or characteristic described by the object. In general, it suggests that the subject's capabilities or properties enable it to make informed guesses about the nature of the object.

Predicate-achieves.label: achieves
Predicate-achieves.description: Indicates that the subject has successfully attained or obtained a specific level or standard represented by the object.

Predicate-is_divided_into.label: is divided into
Predicate-is_divided_into.description: The predicate 'is divided into' indicates a partitioning or segmentation of the subject into distinct parts or categories, as specified by the object. It implies that the subject has been organized or structured according to some criteria, and the resulting divisions are reflected in the object.

Predicate-describe.label: describe
Predicate-describe.description: To describe a subject means to provide an account or explanation of its characteristics, properties, features, or nature. The predicate 'describe' establishes a connection between the subject and object by conveying information about the subject's attributes, aspects, or essence.

Predicate-apply_for_this_research_projec.label: apply for this research project
Predicate-apply_for_this_research_projec.description: To express interest and submit a proposal to participate or collaborate on a specific research project.

Predicate-brings.label: brings
Predicate-brings.description: The predicate 'brings' indicates a relationship where the subject (a person or entity) contributes to or introduces something new into existence, often in a context that involves planning, creation, or presentation. The object of this action can be an idea, concept, design, plan, or other abstract construct.

Predicate-are_introduced_in_this_section.label: are introduced in this section about
Predicate-are_introduced_in_this_section.description: This predicate indicates a connection between the subject and object by providing context or background information that relates to the topic of discussion. It suggests that the subject (experimental settings in this case) is being discussed within the scope of the section, with specific details about it provided in relation to the object (hardware platforms).

Predicate-gives.label: gives
Predicate-gives.description: Indicates a transfer of possession or control from the subject to the object. The predicate 'gives' implies that the subject has authority over the object and is intentionally transferring it, its benefits, or its value to someone else.

Predicate-proves_its_feasibility.label: proves its feasibility
Predicate-proves_its_feasibility.description: To prove something's feasibility means to demonstrate that it can be successfully implemented or achieved. In this context, the predicate 'proves its feasibility' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, where the subject (e.g., an idea, plan, or proposal) is shown to have the potential for successful execution by providing evidence or demonstrating effectiveness through the object (e.g., experimental results).

Predicate-can_briefly_introduce_the_esse.label: can briefly introduce the essential features of the research proposals to help human evaluators better screen the excellent research proposals
Predicate-can_briefly_introduce_the_esse.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g., Data mining models) with an object (e.g., 21st century), indicating that the subject has the ability to concisely highlight the key aspects of research proposals, thereby facilitating human evaluators in identifying outstanding proposals. The predicate suggests that the subject can provide a concise overview or summary of the essential features of the research proposals, making it easier for evaluators to quickly identify and prioritize excellent submissions.

Predicate-evaluating.label: evaluating
Predicate-evaluating.description: The predicate 'evaluating' indicates a process of assessing or judging the quality, relevance, or suitability of something (the object), based on specific criteria or standards, by an entity or organization with expertise in that area (the subject).

Predicate-proposed.label: proposed
Predicate-proposed.description: To propose means to suggest or recommend something as a solution, method, or idea. It implies that the subject has put forward an option for consideration and evaluation by others.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a relationship where the subject relies on or derives its foundation from the object. It suggests that the subject's existence, validity, or meaning are grounded in or connected to the characteristics, principles, or concepts represented by the object.

Predicate-was_used_to_determine.label: was used to determine
Predicate-was_used_to_determine.description: This predicate indicates that the subject played a role in establishing or identifying the object. The subject served as a means or tool for determining the nature or value of the object, which may involve evaluation, measurement, calculation, or other forms of analysis.

Predicate-used.label: used
Predicate-used.description: The predicate 'used' indicates that a subject has employed or utilized an object to achieve some purpose or effect. It suggests a relationship of application, exploitation, or utilization between the subject and the object.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship where the subject entity employs or relies on the object entity as part of its functioning, operation, or process. This connection implies that the subject uses the object to achieve some goal, perform an action, or solve a problem.

Predicate-was_used_to_group.label: was used to group
Predicate-was_used_to_group.description: The predicate 'was used to group' indicates that a subject (an entity or process) played a role in organizing or categorizing an object into distinct groups, categories, or clusters. This connection implies that the subject was employed as a means of achieving this grouping outcome.

Predicate-showed_that.label: showed that
Predicate-showed_that.description: Indicates a conclusion or inference drawn from evidence presented by the subject. The predicate 'showed that' establishes a causal link between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject's findings or results demonstrate or prove the truth of the object.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects the subject to the object by indicating a relationship of conjunction or combination. It suggests that the subject and object are related in some way, often implying equivalence, similarity, or unity.

Predicate-used_in.label: used in
Predicate-used_in.description: The predicate 'used in' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or technique) is applied to or employed within the context of the object (an activity, field, or domain).

Predicate-are_treated_as_equally_importa.label: are treated as equally important
Predicate-are_treated_as_equally_importa.description: This predicate indicates that the subject and object have equivalent significance or value. It suggests a relationship of parity or symmetry between the two entities, implying that they are considered equally valuable, relevant, or influential.

Predicate-only_pay_attention_to_a_certai.label: only pay attention to a certain of words
Predicate-only_pay_attention_to_a_certai.description: This predicate indicates that the subject's focus or consideration is limited to specific and particular aspects or elements within the object. It implies a selective attention process where the subject prioritizes certain words over others, highlighting their importance in understanding the context.

Predicate-usually_do_not_represent_impor.label: usually do not represent important in most cases
Predicate-usually_do_not_represent_impor.description: This predicate indicates that a relationship or phenomenon described by the subject does not typically have significant consequences or implications for the object. It suggests that the connection between the subject and object is often superficial, trivial, or unremarkable.

Predicate-adjusts.label: adjusts
Predicate-adjusts.description: The predicate 'adjusts' indicates a process of modifying or refining something to achieve a desired state. It implies an intentional action that affects the object's properties, values, or relationships in some way.

Predicate-was_proposed_based_on.label: was proposed based on
Predicate-was_proposed_based_on.description: The predicate 'was proposed based on' indicates a relationship between an idea or concept (the subject) and its underlying foundation or inspiration (the object). It suggests that the subject was developed, created, or justified using the principles, methods, or ideas represented by the object. In general, this predicate highlights the connection between a solution or approach and the theoretical or empirical basis upon which it is grounded.

Predicate-proposed_(1).label: proposed
Predicate-proposed_(1).description: To propose refers to suggesting or putting forward an idea, concept, method, or solution. It implies a deliberate act of presenting something as a viable option for consideration, discussion, or implementation.

Predicate-was_used_to_measure.label: was used to measure
Predicate-was_used_to_measure.description: The predicate 'was used to measure' indicates that the subject (a method or tool) played a role in quantifying or evaluating the object (some aspect, property, or characteristic). It implies a causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject's purpose was to provide insight into the nature of the object.

Predicate-performed_better_than.label: performed better than
Predicate-performed_better_than.description: This predicate indicates a comparative evaluation between two entities (subject and object), suggesting that the subject has demonstrated superior performance or quality compared to the object.

Predicate-proposed_for.label: proposed for
Predicate-proposed_for.description: The predicate 'proposed for' indicates a relationship where an entity (subject) has been suggested or put forward as being suitable or applicable to achieve a specific goal, task, or purpose (object).

Predicate-is_about.label: is about
Predicate-is_about.description: The predicate 'is about' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject provides an overview or summary of the topic described by the object. It suggests that the subject has some relevance, connection, or focus on the concept, idea, or domain represented by the object.

Predicate-relates_to.label: relates to
Predicate-relates_to.description: The predicate 'relates to' indicates a connection between two concepts or domains where one concept (the subject) has relevance, significance, or association with another concept (the object).

Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.label: can be interpreted to mean that
Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's meaning or significance can be understood as equivalent to or conveying the same idea as the object. In other words, it suggests that there exists an interpretation or analogy between the two entities.

Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.label: can be interpreted to mean that
Predicate-can_be_interpreted_to_mean_tha.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the meaning or significance of the subject can be understood as equivalent to the statement expressed by the object. In other words, it suggests that there exists an interpretation or analogy between the two entities.

Predicate-depends_independently_on.label: depends independently on
Predicate-depends_independently_on.description: The predicate 'depends independently on' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., Decision Tree) has its own inherent characteristics or properties that are not directly influenced by, but rather complemented by, the object (e.g., random sample). In this sense, the subject's behavior or performance is autonomous and unaffected by the presence of the object. The predicate highlights a state of independence between the subject and object.

Predicate-votes.label: votes
Predicate-votes.description: The predicate 'votes' represents a process of selection or preference among options. It indicates that the subject (in this case, Random Forest  RF) makes decisions or assigns weights to each tree in specific classification problems.

Predicate-selects.label: selects
Predicate-selects.description: The predicate 'selects' indicates a process of choosing or identifying one option from multiple possibilities, resulting in a specific outcome that connects the subject to the object. It implies an intentional action by the subject to determine the most suitable or relevant entity among others.

Predicate-are_welcome_for_its_advantage_.label: are welcome for its advantage of showing how models make decisions according to the data features
Predicate-are_welcome_for_its_advantage_.description: This predicate describes a relationship where the subject (e.g., Data mining models) are accepted or valued for their ability to demonstrate how they make decisions based on specific characteristics of the data features. The object (e.g., Decision Tree  DT) represents an instance or example that exemplifies this decision-making process, highlighting its advantages and capabilities.

Predicate-compared.label: compared
Predicate-compared.description: The predicate 'compared' indicates a relationship of similarity or equivalence between two entities. It suggests that the subject and object are being evaluated against each other, with the goal of identifying commonalities, differences, or relative merits.

Predicate-according_to.label: according to
Predicate-according_to.description: Indicates that a statement or claim about something (object) is being attributed to an authority, source, or perspective (not explicitly mentioned in this triple), which provides the basis for understanding or interpreting the subject.

Predicate-implemented_with.label: implemented with
Predicate-implemented_with.description: The predicate 'implemented with' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and a method or approach used to create or develop that entity. The object represents the specific technique, framework, tool, or strategy employed to bring the subject into being.

Predicate-applied.label: applied
Predicate-applied.description: The predicate 'applied' indicates that a method or technique (subject) was used to implement or utilize another concept or approach (object), often resulting in some practical application, analysis, or solution.

Predicate-were_compared_with.label: were compared with
Predicate-were_compared_with.description: Indicates a comparison or evaluation of two entities (subject and object), suggesting that their characteristics, properties, or performance are being assessed against each other.

Predicate-was_compared.label: was compared
Predicate-was_compared.description: Indicates that two or more entities were evaluated and analyzed against each other to determine their relative merits, strengths, or differences. This predicate connects a subject (a method, algorithm, model, etc.) with an object (another method, algorithm, model, etc.), implying a comparison between the two.

Predicate-classified_by.label: classified by
Predicate-classified_by.description: The predicate 'classified by' indicates a relationship where the subject (a set of entities or data points) has been categorized, grouped, or assigned to specific categories based on characteristics extracted from it using the object (an algorithm, model, or method).

Predicate-was_used_to_classify.label: was used to classify
Predicate-was_used_to_classify.description: The predicate 'was used to classify' indicates that a particular method or technique (subject) was employed for the purpose of categorizing or grouping data into predefined categories, with respect to a specific dataset or collection (object).

Predicate-were_used.label: were used
Predicate-were_used.description: Indicates that a method or technique was employed to analyze, process, or utilize something. The subject refers to the entity responsible for using the object, which represents the thing being used.

Predicate-was_used_to_evaluate.label: was used to evaluate
Predicate-was_used_to_evaluate.description: The predicate 'was used to evaluate' indicates a relationship where the subject (a tool or method) played a role in assessing or judging the object, which represents some kind of entity or information. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject was employed as an instrument for making decisions, assessments, or judgments about the object.

Predicate-details.label: details
Predicate-details.description: To detail means to provide a comprehensive explanation or description of something. It connects the subject (a concept, process, or methodology) with its constituent parts, highlighting key aspects and providing insight into how they work together. In this sense, 'details' predicates describe the relationship between an abstract entity and its underlying structure, mechanisms, or components.

Predicate-shows.label: shows
Predicate-shows.description: The predicate 'shows' indicates a relationship where the subject presents or displays information about the object, often providing insight, illustration, or demonstration. It suggests that the subject serves as a medium for conveying knowledge, data, or understanding related to the object.

Predicate-used_to_analyse_the_grant_appl.label: used to analyse the grant applications is
Predicate-used_to_analyse_the_grant_appl.description: The predicate 'used to analyse the grant applications is' indicates a historical or past purpose of the subject (data sets, in this case), which was to analyze specific types of grant applications. This connection highlights that the data sets were designed or intended for analyzing grant applications at some point in time.

Predicate-includes.label: includes
Predicate-includes.description: The predicate 'includes' indicates that the subject contains or comprises the object as a part of its entirety. It suggests a relationship where the subject encompasses, covers, or has within it the scope or essence of the object.

Predicate-are_saved_in.label: are saved in
Predicate-are_saved_in.description: The predicate 'are saved in' indicates a relationship of storage or containment between the subject and object. It suggests that the information or data represented by the subject (in this case, research proposals) are physically stored or held within the format or medium specified as the object (PDF).

Predicate-saved_in.label: saved in
Predicate-saved_in.description: The predicate 'saved in' indicates a relationship where the subject (e.g., data, documents, or other digital content) has been stored or preserved within the object (e.g., a file format, database, or storage medium). This connection suggests that the subject is contained or archived within the object, often for purposes of organization, preservation, or accessibility.

Predicate-are_stored_in.label: are stored in
Predicate-are_stored_in.description: The predicate 'are stored in' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject's data or content is held or maintained by the object. The object serves as a repository, container, or medium for storing the subject's information.

Predicate-is_based_on.label: is based on
Predicate-is_based_on.description: The predicate 'is based on' indicates a relationship where the subject (a statistical analysis) relies on or draws its foundation from the object ('innovation and creativity' IC scores). This connection suggests that the subject is grounded, justified, or informed by the information provided in the object. In general, this predicate implies a causal link between the two entities, implying that the existence or validity of the subject depends on or stems from the content of the object.

Predicate-shows_a_statistic_of.label: shows a statistic of
Predicate-shows_a_statistic_of.description: The predicate 'shows a statistic of' indicates that the subject (a table or other data presentation) displays and highlights specific numerical information about the object (typically, a set of scores or values), providing context for understanding the presented statistics.

Predicate-have_valid_IC_scores.label: have valid IC scores
Predicate-have_valid_IC_scores.description: The predicate 'have valid IC scores' indicates that a subject (e.g., research proposal) possesses or meets certain standards of quality as measured by Internal Consistency (IC) scores, which are typically used to evaluate the reliability and validity of assessments. This connection implies that the subject has been evaluated against these criteria and found satisfactory.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship between the subject and object where the subject possesses or holds the described property or characteristic denoted by the object. This can include possession, ownership, measurement, classification, or other forms of association.

Predicate-is_for.label: is for
Predicate-is_for.description: The predicate 'is for' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action or process. It connects the subject (the entity performing the action) to the object, suggesting that the subject is directed towards achieving or fulfilling the purpose described by the object.

Predicate-proved_that.label: proved that
Predicate-proved_that.description: The predicate 'proved that' indicates a causal relationship between the subject (the entity performing the action of proving) and the object (a statement, claim, or hypothesis), where the subject demonstrates evidence or argumentation to support the truthfulness of the object.

Predicate-of.label: of
